where_to_read: Leaves of grass are all up in my stuff

reviews.review_text: Great snapshot of history of eastern Europe.
If you're studying International Relations, this is  a must read

This books is a must read for all students studying the Cold War. The literature I read before, including the ones I read when I was studying the Cold War at Yale, was cold and emotionless. This book makes you understand and examine more closely the states of mind of people who went through the event in their daily lives, instead of just listing all the events and dates out.
It is for a class, a bit dry in the reading and too much personal information about the author in the midst of the text.

Ash is like a fly on the wall during all of the revolutions in Eastern Europe.  I have no idea how he managed to be present at crucial planning meetings and to be a witness to events, but I have enjoyed reading his book!
This book was not particularly well written, and while it does include some interesting information about the 1989-90 revolutions it is too much from the "I was there" school of writing.

Probably the best book on Prague I've read since I've been here — but not sure if it would be great if I wasn't here. Very personal, nuanced within its own (clearly defined and large) limitations of concision, personal history, and breadth.

It's dated -- written in the spring of 1990 -- but it's great first-hand coverage of the events of 1989 in Warsaw, Budapest, E. Berlin, and Prague. The Prague narrative is the best, as you see how a group of artists and dissidents went from discussing protest actions to discovering, somewhat to their owm amazement, that the government was peacefully falling into their hands.

title: The Magic Lantern: The Revolution of '89 Witnessed in Warsaw, Budapest, Berlin, and Prague
word_cloud: great snapshot history eastern studying student study literature include one study cold emotionless make understand closely state mind people go event daily live instead listing event date class bit dry reading much personal information author midst text fly wall revolution idea manage present crucial planning meeting event enjoy read particularly well write include interesting information revolution much school write good stuff thank probably best sure great personal nuanced clearly define large limitation concision personal history breadth date write spring great coverage event narrative best see group artists dissident go discuss protest action discover somewhat own amazement government peacefully fall hand
summary:
The Magic Lantern is one of those rare books that define a historic moment, written by a brilliant witness who was also a participant in epochal events. Whether covering Poland’s first free parliamentary elections—in which Solidarity found itself in the position of trying to limit the scope of its victory—or sitting in at the meetings of an unlikely coalition of bohemian intellectuals and Catholic clerics orchestrating the liberation of Czechoslovakia, Garton Ash writes with enormous sympathy and power.

"A wonderful combination of first-class reporting, brilliant political analysis and reflection." The New York Times
story_arc:
Bad luck, followed by promise, ending in a
                    final fall
